div1.p: These special orders include a section appointing Reed, Vaughan, and Shakespeare to a board for the purpose of investigating the cause of the prevalence of typhoid fever in U.S. military camps. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, Victor C. Vaughan, and Edward O. Shakespeare, August 18, 1898 [selected pages]
div1.p:
SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 194. }

WAR DEPARTMENT,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, August 18, 1898.

1. Private Ernest F. Thomas, Company C, 4th U. S. Volun-
teer Infantry, now in this city, will be sent to the station of
his company, Jacksonville, Florida.

The Subsistence Department will pay commutation of ra-
tions in advance at the prescribed rate for two days, it
being impracticable for this soldier to carry rations of any
kind.

2. Private James A. Pownell, Company B, 15th Infantry,
now at Fort Grant, Arizona Territory, is transferred as 2d
class private to the Signal Corps, U. S. A. He will be as-
signed to duty in charge of the military telegraph office at
Cedar Springs, Arizona Territory.

3. Private Charles W. Brown, Troop A, 7th Cavalry, now
at Fort Du Chesne, Utah, is transferred as 2d class private to
the Signal Corps, U. S. Army, and assigned to duty at the
military telegraph office at that post.

4. Private Corwin M. Ferguson, Company G, 4th Virginia
Volunteer Infantry, now at Jacksonville, Florida, having
enlisted under false pretences, will be discharged without
honor from the service of the United States on receipt of this
order by the commanding officer of his station. Under para-
graph 1386 of the Regulations the soldier is not entitled to
pay or allowances, and final statements, except for deposits,
shall not be furnished him.

5. Private Ora G. Spencer, Company D, 1st U. S. Volun-
teer Infantry, now at Santiago, Cuba, will be discharged from
the service of the United States by the commanding officer of
his station. Under paragraph 1386 of the Regulations the
soldier is not entitled to pay or allowances, and final state-
ments, except for deposits, shall not be furnished him.

6. Private Richard M. Williamson, Company A, 2d Ala-
bama Volunteer Infantry, now at Jacksonville, Florida, will
be discharged the service of the United States by the com-
manding officer of his station. This soldier is not entitled to
travel-pay.

7. Private Jesse Hood Bullock, Company M, 1st Georgia
Volunteer Infantry, now at Camp George H. Thomas, Georgia,
will be discharged the service of the United States by the

35. Captain William F. Lewis, assistant surgeon, U. S.
Army, now at Sullivans Island, South Carolina, will proceed
at once to Tampa, Florida, and report in person to the com-
manding officer, 5th U. S. Infantry, to accompany that regi-
ment to Santiago. The travel enjoined is necessary for the
public service.

36. Acting Assistant Surgeon Compton Wilson, U. S. Army,
will proceed from Norfolk to Fort Monroe, Virginia, and re-
port in person to Major Calvin De Witt, surgeon, U. S. Army,
in charge of U. S. General Hospital at that post, to await
transportation by the U. S. Steamer “Obdam,” to Ponce,
Porto Rico, and, upon arrival there, will report in person to
the commanding general of the troops at that place, for as-
signment to duty. The travel enjoined is necessary for the
public service.

37. Majors Merrill W. Lang and Jacob M. Longnecker, ad-
ditional paymasters, U. S. Volunteers, now on temporary duty
in this city, under verbal instructions from the Secretary of
War, are assigned to station in Washington, District of
Columbia, to date from August 11, 1898.

38. Lieutenant Colonel Edward B. Ives, U. S. Volunteer
Signal Corps, having reported to the Chief Signal Officer of
the Army, en route to Camp Russell A. Alger, Virginia, will
proceed to Middletown, Pennsylvania, and report in person
to the commanding general, 2d Army Corps, for assignment
to duty as Chief Signal Officer of that corps. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.

39. Acting Assistant Surgeon Harry Streett, U. S. Army,
will proceed from Baltimore, Maryland, to Charleston, South
Carolina, and await transportation by U. S. Steamer “Obdam”
to Ponce, Porto Rico, and, upon arrival there, will report in
person to the commanding general of the troops at that place,
for assignment to duty. The travel enjoined is necessary for
the public service.
✓ 40. A board of medical officers, to consist of--

Major Walter Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army;
Major Victor C. Vaughan, division surgeon, U. S. Volun-
teers; and
Major Edward O. Shakespeare, brigade surgeon, U. S. Vol-
unteers,
is appointed to meet in this city at the earliest date practica-
7
ble for the purpose of making an investigation into the cause
of the extensive prevalence of typhoid fever in the various
military camps within the limits of the United States, under
such instructions as it may receive from the Surgeon General
of the Army. The board will call the attention of the proper
commanding officers to any insanitary conditions which may
exist at the camps visited by it, and will make recommenda-
tions with a view to their proper correction. The report of
the board will be forwarded to the Surgeon General as soon
as practicable after the completion of the investigation con-
templated.

Such journeys as may be required under the above order ↓
are necessary for the public service.

41. Private Emil Ballhaus, Company A, 1st Ohio Volunteer
Infantry, now at Fernandina, Florida, is, upon his own ap-
plication, transferred to the 2d Kentucky Volunteer Infantry,
and will be sent to the station of that regiment, Camp George
H. Thomas, Georgia. The expenses of the transfer will be
borne by the soldier, and transportation will not be furnished
by the Quartermaster's Department.

42. Sergeant George L. Rubadon, Company C, 31st Michi-
gan Volunteer Infantry, now at Camp George H. Thomas,
Georgia, will be discharged the service of the United States
by the commanding officer of his station. This soldier is not
entitled to travel-pay.

43. Private Benjamin E. Sprague, Company G, 35th Michi-
gan Volunteer Infantry, now at Island Lake, Michigan,
will be discharged the service of the United States by the
commanding officer of his station. This soldier is not entitled
to travel-pay.

44. Principal Musician Charles J. Rulo, 4th Ohio Volunteer
Infantry, now in Porto Rico, will be discharged the service
of the United States by the commanding officer of his station.
This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

45. Private Louis F. Wurster, Company E, 20th Infantry,
now at Fort McPherson, Georgia, will be discharged the
service of the United States by the commanding officer of
his station. This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

46. Private Amos R. E. Pinchot, Troop A, New York Vol-
unteer Cavalry, now in Porto Rico, will be discharged the
service of the United States by the commanding officer of his
station. This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.
